data.title: Grindr: A Riskier Bet As Buyout Offer Is Off The Table (Downgrade)
data.description:
In a stock market that is rife with volatility in 2026, stock picking has become more essential than ever. The S&P 500 continues to dance in a nervous fashion near all-time highs, though sector leadership is changing drastically. "Old economy" companies in the energy and materials sectors are rallying, while tech stocks, particularly in the software space, have quickly descended to becoming bargain plays.

Another deep bargain is Grindr Inc. (GRND), the gay dating app that rivals Match Group's (MTCH) Tinder and Hinge. Shares of Grindr have lost one-third of their value over the past year, not only due to compression in growth rates but also because a recent offer to take the company private at $18 per share was rejected by Grindr's board. The question for investors now is, can Grindr rebound from here?

I last wrote a "Buy" article on Grindr in November, when the stock was trading around $13 per share. While I never buy any individual stock because of M&A potential alone, I think the removal of buyout possibility for Grindr also eliminates the near-term catalyst that could have triggered share price appreciation in this stock. And while Grindr remains cheap, a number of risks have also popped up, especially as the company moves to report user data less frequently in FY26, giving us less visibility into how the company is remaining competitive with other dating apps.

Another big factor: while Grindr has always been appealing due to its price, many deep-value buying opportunities have just opened up in the software sector. Once high-flying stocks like HubSpot (HUBS) and Atlassian (TEAM) are now trading at deep discounts to their historical multiples. These are enterprise-facing, recurring revenue businesses that are technically "safer" than a company like Grindr, whose revenue base depends on its ability to retain users - which may be a shakier proposition amid pending price increases and a weaker macroeconomy. With all of these factors in mind, I'm dropping my rating on Grindr to "Neutral."

At current share prices, I see more of a balanced bull-and-bear case for Grindr. On the bright side of the coin:

  • Grindr's value proposition is accented by the company's recent share buyback proposal. The company noted in its Q4 shareholder letter that it's expanding its buyback program by $400 million to demonstrate to the markets that it believes its current share price is undervalued (which it more or less has to do when it rejected a take-private offer at $18 per share). This buyback covers nearly 20% of Grindr's current market cap, a huge sum.
  • Taking share as Tinder stalls. Tinder, the world's largest dating app, continues to see a decline in payers, while Grindr is adding both total MAUs (monthly active users) and paid users.

At the same time, however, we do have to be cognizant of the risks that the company faces:

  • Less frequent user data reporting. Beginning in 2026, Grindr is shifting to reporting MAUs on an annual basis. While the company notes this is in line with peers (and main rival Match doesn't report MAUs at all, only paid users), we do think that if Grindr had better news to share, it wouldn't be reducing its cadence of user reporting.
  • Possible blowback after price increases. Grindr is increasing monthly subscription prices on its XTRA and Premium plans to $23 and $45, respectively, from the current $20 and $40, which the company says reflects an expanded feature set. In a tougher macroeconomy where fewer people are willing to pay for internet services, including dating apps, this may end up turning into a headwind rather than a tailwind for the company.
  • Debt load. Grindr has a net debt position of ~$0.3 billion. While its share buyback appears favorable on paper, the buyback is well exceeding the company's adjusted EBITDA profit guidance for 2026 and will likely increase the company's debt load and leverage ratios substantially.

The core balancing factor here, however, is valuation. At Grindr's current share prices near $12, the stock trades at a market cap of $2.16 billion. Netting off the $87.0 million of cash and $395.9 million of debt on Grindr's most recent balance sheet gives us an enterprise value of $2.47 billion.

For FY26, the company is guiding to a minimum of $528 million in revenue (+20% y/y) and $217 million in adjusted EBITDA (+11% y/y), which implies an erosion to a 4.11% margin (versus 44.5% in FY26) if the company only achieves its minimum threshold.

Even if we take Grindr's minimum $217 million EBITDA at face value, the stock trades at 11.4x EV/FY26 adjusted EBITDA - a bargain for a company that is achieving >20% y/y revenue growth and does have potential tailwinds from both payer market share growth and price increases.

That said, I also don't think there's any room for upward correction in Grindr's multiples, with the near-term buyout possibility being removed. Amid the abundance of more appealing bargains in the tech sector that are available after the "SaaSpocalypse" of 2026, I'd prefer to move to the sidelines here and invest elsewhere.

Q4 Download

Let's now run through Grindr's latest quarterly results in greater detail. The Q4 earnings summary is shown below:

Grindr's revenue grew 29% y/y to $126.0 million in the quarter, which beat Wall Street's expectations of $122.1 million (+25% y/y) by a four-point margin.

Meanwhile, the company's MAUs rose 5% y/y to 15.0 million. This was a sequential reduction versus 15.1 million users in Q3; however, we do note that the company has been cleaning up profiles on its platform, which led to the removal of 350k users in the second half of FY25. As such, we're not clear on whether, excluding these actions, the company grew MAUs sequentially (though growth outside of these profile removals would have been stronger at 6% y/y).

Meanwhile, average paid users grew 17% y/y to 1.26 million. We can read this result in two ways. First, we note that Match has opened up an additional decimal point on its paid user reporting (in Q3, the company had merely cited 1.3 million paid users). Year-over-year growth rates remained consistent with Q3 (also at 17% y/y growth), but given the sequential downtick in MAUs, it's likely that Grindr also saw a seasonal decline in paid users.

That said, Grindr is doing materially better than Tinder and Match Group overall. Match's overall payers fell 5% y/y to 13.8 million in Q4, with Tinder facing a 12% y/y decline (partially being cannibalized by Match's own Hinge, which grew 17% y/y but at a much smaller base). This continues to suggest that Grindr is taking market share in the dating app space.

The big unknown lies next year, when prices increase ~15% for XTRA and ~13% for Premium. The core test will be for Grindr to maintain similar double-digit y/y growth rates in paid users while benefiting from an ARPU bump from higher prices. The company's guidance, which calls for at least 20% y/y revenue growth next year (which implies a meaningful bump from price increases), sets an optimistic tone for the anticipated impacts of this price change.

On the profitability front, Grindr's adjusted EBITDA rose 42% y/y to $54.9 million, with margins rising 400 bps y/y to 43.6%.

The company's expectations of a margin decay next year reflect the recent burst of investments into new features and AI capabilities. That said, we do expect that Grindr will be able to exceed its current FY26 outlook, which is set rather conservatively.

Key Takeaways

In my view, investors no longer have a substantial near-term reward for investing in Grindr, given that the $18 per share offer is off the table. The company will have to prove that it's able to accelerate revenue growth via its subscription price increases next year without triggering substantial user churn in a tough macroeconomy.

Grindr remains cheap, especially given its plans to buy back a substantial amount of stock (and presumably raise leverage in the process). But with so many other bargains available in today's market, I'm choosing to invest my portfolio elsewhere for now.

data.title: Root: Growing But Volatile Auto Insurtech Play
data.description:
Root, Inc. (ROOT) just reported Q4 and full-year 2025 earnings. Having executed on growth in line with previous expectations, and with a better valuation, I have returned to giving ROOT a Buy rating.

Summary of Previous Thesis

When I wrote about Root in August, I gave another Hold rating. The company continued to show strong revenue growth, but its expenses were growing too.

A digital auto insurer, one might have thought this was due to higher claims, but loss ratio actually remained low compared to previous quarters. Rather, it was their overhead that had increased.

This meant that 2025's quarterly EPS numbers were a bit lower than those achieved in Q3 and Q4 of last year. With the balance remaining healthy, it was largely a question of how much one paid for growth. With less than 1% of the American car insurance market and effective dealer-distributor network, I believed they could continue growth. I used then-current EPS figures to calculate future tangible book value ("TBV") per share in ten years, with a range of earnings growth possibilities:

  • 0% CAGR: $53.89
  • 10% CAGR: $84.01
  • 20% CAGR: $138.49

Close to $90 per share at the time, ROOT seemed fairly valued, worth buying if it fell below $84. This would price it for low growth and to benefit from a higher Price/TBV multiple than 1, making it effective for low risk and high reward.

Full-Year 2025 Results

Root's financial performance for 2025 was one of continued growth in the underlying business, but higher costs pulled down on EPS. Let's look at the important figures that impact revenue and earnings growth.

Gross premiums written grew from $1.3B in 2024 to $1.5B in 2025. Loss ratio also remained relatively stable for the year.

Earnings, meanwhile, were higher but didn't increase by quite the same volume implied by premium growth. Moreover, combined ratio was higher, despite the stable loss ratios.

Losses grew in proportion to the top line, but customer acquisition costs grew faster, seen in the rises of sales and marketing expense and other insurance expense. During the earnings call, CFO Megan Binkley explained:

The year-over-year decreases reflect deliberate investments in partnership acquisition and direct R&D marketing as well as a modest increase in loss ratio due to elevated seasonality. We accelerated policies in force growth by more than double the pace of the fourth quarter of 2024.

This shows some interesting patterns between prior-year quarters and the full years, regarding EPS data. With their first GAAP quarter in Q3 2024, Root was more freshly profitable with its book of business at that time, posting Q4 2024 diluted EPS of $1.30, which fell to $0.31 in 2025. Since they entered 2025 profitable, however, the full year's diluted EPS of $2.36 was higher than 2024's $1.83. Policy losses fluctuate in different quarters, as well as acquisition costs. While many focus on EPS alone, a balance sheet is still very important with an insurance company.

The year's results show a much better balance sheet. Cash grew by $70M to $669M. Total investments grew by $80M to $391M. Long-term debt remained stable at $200M. Overall, book value per share grew from $13.49 to $18.34 in 2025.

Outlook and Valuation

Trading near $57 per share, ROOT is the cheapest it's been in a long time. Let's make the price into a practical matter, however. As Root is an insurance underwriter, stock price is a bet on its future book value per share. Using 2025' diluted EPS of $2.36 as a baseline, we can make growth assumptions about book value per share over time by adding it to the current book value of $18.34.

To simplify things from my previous theses, I'll only show a high end and a low end.

  • 0% CAGR: $41.94
  • 15% CAGR: $73.44

Flat EPS for ten years gives a book value of $42, while a 15% CAGR would bring it to $73. I didn't mention this before because I was more focused on basic book value, I think Root has maintained profits while growing long enough that we can consider it.

Above are the last five years of ROOT's P/B, compared to those of Progressive (PGR) and Allstate (ALL), simply because they are well-known auto insurance businesses.

PGR has been at 5x plenty of times, and ALL has traded above 2x very often. In 2025, PGR and ALL had 16.73% and 10.19% (respectively) of the US auto insurance market. Root, meanwhile, is closing in on 1%, giving ample room for growth ahead as long as they continue to execute.

Growth is driven by competitive pricing (from their data-driven model built on customer miles driven), for one. The real clincher is their very effective distribution strategy. In addition to B2C from their accessible mobile app, Root has partnered with dealers and manufacturers, seamlessly embedding into partners' platforms.

This stands out from the advertising approaches that other insurers take. Over time, cost of acquisition fades away, but advertising budgets do not. At their size, they simply need to penetrate distribution networks well enough to steal market share from other small insurers. They do not need to compete materially with PGR, ALL, or other big players quite so much.

Risk Factors

There are a couple of things that stand out as long-term risk factors, the kind that would affect big and small alike:

  • Disruption by superior software/AI from a rival
  • Disruption by fully automated self-driving

Root is an "insurtech" play. Just as PGR broke into the scene in the 2010s with its more tech-driven approach, Root is doing the same now. It remains possible that some kind of operational workaround that they haven't anticipated affects them, just as they are affecting their peers.

The latter is the more curious one. It's one thing if a better AI agent outplays Root's distribution strategy (even if Root uses AI too). AI that takes the human operator out of driving fundamentally changes the game of auto insurance. S&P Global wrote about the mixed ways this could lead to higher or lower premiums:

As automation reduces crashes, fewer claims are expected, but repair costs may rise. AVs contain expensive components such as lidar, sensors, and high-performance processors known as system-on-chip (SoC). The rise of EVs previews this dynamic. While EVs are safer in some respects and mechanically simpler than internal combustion vehicles, they can still be more expensive to repair due to costly parts, limited technician expertise, and tightly integrated systems.

The question for ROOT shareholders is if fewer claims do not come with higher costs. A smaller risk to underwrite is a smaller premium earned, meaning lower revenue. Root is small enough that it may be able to grow into this trend, but that also relies on awareness and execution of management. As we don't know when such a paradigm shift in auto insurance might occur, uncertainty looms with Root.

Conclusion

Root had another year of GAAP profits. Crucially, it maintained profitability while still spending on growth. The recently low stock price offers an entry that doesn't price in much growth, if any at all. While long-term returns may be attractive, it will be a volatile investment, given the ever-changing nature of insurtech. As the value is good, though, I restore my Buy rating to ROOT.

data.title: AIRR: Reindustrialization Driving Durable Backlog Growth
data.description:
The First Trust RBA American Industrial RenaissanceÂ® ETF (AIRR) is an exchange-traded fund designed to provide investors with diversified exposure to the broader industrials market sector, favoring mid- and large-cap companies. AIRR has performed exceptionally well in recent years, in part due to the renewed growth environment for power, water, and data center infrastructure, leading to a substantial increase in construction projects that has facilitated growth across the market. Within the industrials sector, AIRR will primarily provide investors with exposure to the engineering, procurement, and construction [EPC] industry.

Why Invest in AIRR

AIRR has gained strong momentum in recent years as a result of renewed growth for industrial construction projects led by large-scale data center developments and supporting infrastructure for power & water. As a result of this heightened demand, EPCs have experienced substantial growth in orders, expanding backlogs that support future operational growth. Despite the strong market environment, the industry may be faced with certain bottlenecks that may influence the pace of growth, including labor constraints, materials costs, and volatility in the supply chain (resulting from tariff uncertainty).

Market constraints may not necessarily be diminishing earnings in the industry, given that this is experienced across the entire domestic market. This has, in part, led to greater pricing power being turned over to the EPCs, providing improved operating leverage in a labor-intensive industry. This has also led to robust backlog growth, providing more certainty regarding project planning and revenue growth. For example, Comfort Systems USA, Inc. (FIX), the largest position in AIRR at 3.99% of net assets, reported record earnings and backlog in Q4 2025, supporting record gross margins. Sterling Infrastructure, Inc. (STRL), the second largest holding at 3.93%, reported similar margin-accretive growth and an expanded backlog back in November 2025.

One factor that may impact the timing of projects is materials availability and costs. Though EPCs generally pass through materials costs to the end customers, costs may impact project timing if customers exhibit some constraints in the capital budgets. This could potentially add some unevenness to growth across the industry from quarter to quarter; however, given that many of these projects are multi-year projects, I believe this unevenness may be relatively muted. Availability of materials may have a greater impact on the market relative to pricing, particularly for electrical components, which have been in short supply for the last 7 months in accordance with the ISM-PMI Manufacturing Index.

The other factor that may impact the industry is labor constraints. A tight labor market for construction workers may create some pricing power for the employees and labor unions during salary negotiations, which may ultimately impact the EPC market when the current cycle begins to conclude.

Overall, I believe AIRR may be a great investment opportunity given the durable growth outlay for the EPC market. With increasing backlogs and improving conversion rates, I believe the industry may experience structural growth through at least the end of the decade.

From a trading perspective, AIRR has substantially outperformed the S&P 500 (SPX) in the last year as a result of the improving market environment. As a result of the strong share price return of the underlying portfolio, AIRR exhibits a relatively high trading premium at 30.40x price/earnings, well above the S&P 500âs valuation of 27.55x.

Though valuation should be considered when evaluating whether AIRR is a good buying opportunity, the underlying companiesâ valuations have historically traded at a relative premium during cyclical upswings. The best indicator for investors to consider when investing in AIRR is backlog growth and book-to-bill ratios, or the ratio of new bookings to revenue generated in the quarter or fiscal year. The book-to-bill ratio indicated whether the company brought in more orders relative to backlog and revenue conversion.

A complementary ETF would be the Global X US Infrastructure Development ETF (PAVE), a strategy designed to provide exposure to companies that design and manufacture components used in large industrial and construction projects that may be facilitated by companies held in AIRR. From a valuation perspective, AIRR is slightly more expensive with an aggregate price/earnings ratio of 30.40x, whereas PAVE has a valuation of 29.93x. Despite the relatively high premiums, I believe both strategies exhibit strong growth potential in terms of pricing power and market growth.

There is some overlap between the two portfolios in which PAVE will provide exposure to Sterling Infrastructure, though the weighting is drastically different, with STRL shares accounting for 3.93% of AIRR and 0.73% of PAVE. Other companies that can be found in both portfolios include Everus Construction Group, Inc. (ECG), Arcosa, Inc. (ACA), Argan, Inc. (AGX), Granite Construction Incorporated (GVA), and Tutor Perini Corporation (TPC), amongst others. From a subsector concentration perspective, AIRR will provide a greater concentration in EPC firms, whereas PAVE prioritizes more heavily parts and components, with the exception of its largest holding, Quanta Services, Inc. (PWR), at 3.37%. From an investment perspective, PAVE may benefit from tighter supply chains and pricing power of industrial components. Given the increasing demand for EPC services, AIRR may also benefit from a tight market while mitigating material costs to the end customer.

About First Trust RBA American Industrial RenaissanceÂ® ETF

AIRR was launched by First Trust on March 10, 2014, on the Nasdaq Exchange. AIRR has a net expense ratio of 69 bps, a modest fee for an industry-focused ETF. AIRR has roughly $8.73 billion in net assets, with an average of $77 million in share value changing hands on a daily basis, providing investors with adequate liquidity for active management and industry rotational strategies.

While AIRR is a passively managed strategy, the index it tracks, the Richard Bernstein Advisors American Industrial Renaissance Index, has an active rotational component that makes the Index appealing throughout the business cycle. The Index tracks the performance of small- and mid-cap US companies in the industrials and community banking sectors. RBA uses a cyclical approach to balancing the Index, adjusting exposure to manage risk through the business cycle. This means that the Index actively manages risk throughout the boom and bust cycles the industry experiences over time, concentrating more heavily in small-cap value stocks during growth cycles and large-cap stocks for stability and durability during easing cycles. Given the portfolio's current positioning, one may infer that the market is currently undergoing a growth cycle.

Risks Related to AIRR

AIRR may expose investors to certain risks that should be considered prior to making a final investment decision. AIRR is concentrated in a specific industry within the industrials sector, potentially exposing investors to concentration risk. AIRR primarily invests in US-domiciled companies, exposing investors to a singular market environment that may present greater cyclical risk. Investors must be mindful of company backlogs and new order intake in order to determine the health of the industry and whether it will continue to grow.

Final Thoughts

AIRR presents investors with appealing exposure to the EPC market, which I anticipate will continue to experience market-leading growth for the coming years. With heightened demand for EPC services for power, water, and data center construction projects, I believe the market environment will remain strong for the subsector, leading to consistent growth over the coming years. Despite the high trading premium of the portfolio, EPC firms have historically traded at a relative premium over the broader market index, potentially exhibiting limited abnormal risk by historical trends. With the market exhibiting strong growth tailwinds, I'm expecting AIRR to outperform the S&P 500 (SPY) for the time being, particularly given the growing uncertainty regarding the mega-cap technology stocks held within the broader index. Given the robust outlook for the market, I am recommending AIRR with a Buy rating with a target allocation of 2-4%.

data.title: Cars.com: A Struggling Business As Consumer Traffic Declines
data.description:
In a volatile stock market in 2026, investors have all the opportunity to be very selective about what stocks belong in our portfolios. The so-called âSaaSpocalypseâ has decimated the valuations of many high-quality software companies on overblown AI fears.

In other words, we no longer have to invest in stocks merely for being cheap. To me, thatâs precisely what Cars.com (CARS) is. The used car marketplace is losing its standing among U.S. consumers, with traffic and monthly active users declining, and dealer counts and revenue only showcasing marginal growth. Down by ~25% over the past year, I view Cars.com as a falling knife with no meaningful catalysts to spark a rebound. The stock just fell ~15% after reporting a disastrous Q4 earnings print, and I expect weakness to sustain well into 2026.

I last wrote a "Sell" article on Cars.com in November, when the stock was trading in the mid-$11s. Since then, Cars.com has seen a substantial erosion in value. But unlike the senseless corrections we are seeing elsewhere in the tech sector, we can see plain justification for Cars.com's pullback in its latest results. Growth continues to lag substantially behind its nearest peer, CarGurus (CARG), while the company's positioning not just with wholesale clients but with consumers/car shoppers also appears to be declining. I continue to reiterate my "Sell" rating on this name.

To me, Cars.com is a grab bag of inescapable risks. The core red flags that investors need to watch out for are:

  • Cars.com is barely growing. There's an old yet simple adage: don't trust a tech company that's not growing. Cars.com has generated low-single-digit revenue growth for quite some time, and it's not expecting to improve beyond this in 2026. Meanwhile, the company's core competitor and No. 1 used car marketplace, CarGurus, is racing ahead with much healthier results.
  • Traffic is declining. As a reminder, Cars.com's primary monetization is from paying car dealerships, which utilize Cars.com as an online marketing channel. But ultimately, Cars.com's value is limited to the consumer traffic it can bring in, and currently, that's declining. With Cars.com getting fewer eyeballs, dealers may also be able to negotiate more favorable terms.
  • Dis-economies of scale. Cars.com is suffering from a pullback in operating and adjusted EBITDA margins, as costs rise while revenue remains stagnant.
  • Debt burden. The company is shouldering about $0.4 billion of net debt while also having very thin cash resources on its balance sheet, reducing its financial flexibility.

Really the only thing that Cars.com has going for it is its cheapness. At current share prices near $9, Cars.com trades at a market cap of $543.1 million. Netting off the $56.2 million of cash and $451.5 million of debt on the company's latest balance sheet gives us an enterprise value of $938.4 million.

For FY26, Cars.com is guiding to just 0%-2% y/y revenue growth, which indicates a range of $723.2-$737.7 million. It's also calling for a 29%-30% adjusted EBITDA margin (versus a 29.2% margin in FY25), indicating a midpoint of $215.5 million in adjusted EBITDA (+2% y/y) at 1% revenue growth.

This positions Cars.com's valuation at 4.4x EV/FY26 adjusted EBITDA. Needless to say, this is cheap. But at the same time, cheap small- and mid-cap stocks are now littered in the stock market. We find equally strong bargains in much higher-quality businesses such as RingCentral (RNG), Talkspace (TALK), eToro (ETOR), and direct competitor CarGurus.

In other words, don't get caught buying a value trap here. Sell this stock and invest elsewhere.

Q4 download

Let's now go through Cars.com's latest quarterly results in greater detail. The Q4 earnings summary is shown below:

Cars.com's revenue grew only 1.9% y/y to $183.9 million, only slightly beating Wall Street's expectations of $183.4 million (+1.7% y/y) by a hair. The company continues to grow its dealer business, but its direct relationships with OEMs (automakers) continue to be a headwind as carmakers pull back on their marketing budgets. This has driven OE revenue down 8% y/y to $16.2 million.

What I find most punishing about Cars.com's quarter, however, is the decline in traffic stats for its website. Average monthly unique visitors are down 6% y/y and 15% quarter-over-quarter to 21.7 million. Meanwhile, overall traffic in terms of views declined 3% y/y and 11% sequentially to 138.8 million.

We note that CarGurus, which still claims itself to be the No. 1 used car marketplace, no longer reports exact traffic measures but noted on the Q4 earnings call that traffic is growing (at an unspecified rate). Even from this, we can surmise that Cars.com is losing market share among consumers.

Ultimately, what gives Cars.com value for dealers is its ability to bring in potential new buyer leads, and shrinking traffic downplays that ability. We note that Cars.com barely added any new dealers to its platform in Q4, ending with 19,544 paying dealers (up 2% y/y and adding only 18 new dealers sequentially).

Meanwhile, CarGurus added 306 new U.S. dealers in the quarter (and many more international dealers, a market in which Cars.com doesn't play at all) while growing average revenue per dealer at 8% y/y. Cars.com's average revenue per dealer, meanwhile, was flat y/y.

To me, directly comparing Cars.com against its larger peer exposes how much less competitive Cars.com is in its industry.

Adding insult to injury is the fact that opex is rising faster than revenue. As a result, the company's adjusted EBITDA was flat y/y at $55 million, with adjusted EBITDA margins declining 90bps y/y.

Key takeaways

We're in a market environment with an abundance of deep value among small- and mid-cap software stocks, and we have a broad selection of high-quality names that suffered in the "SaaSpocalypse" to choose from. Cars.com isn't worth betting on: its growth has stagnated to virtually zero, while end-consumer traffic to its website is in a y/y decline.

With no easy catalysts that can spark a fundamental rebound for this company, Cars.com remains a clear "Sell."

data.title: Revisiting Comparative Valuations In Light Of Nvidia's Earnings (Upgrade)
data.description:
Yesterday, NVIDIA Corporation (NVDA) posted incredible earnings for the period ending Jan. 25, with revenue climbing 73% year-over-year and earnings per share of $1.62, both above expectations. For its upcoming fiscal first quarter, Nvidia expects revenue of approximately $78B. Analysts had expected the company to generate $72.78B in revenue.

And its stock price dropped more than 5%. Go figure!

This led me to update my PEG valuation comparison from last year, and the results were very revealing, so I decided to share them.

Updated PEG Ratio Analysis

I believe that P/E Growth Ratios (PEG) are the most important valuation metric for growing companies. PEG = PE / Expected EPS Growth. So, if a company has a P/E of 25 and is expected to grow earnings at 15% annually, its PEG is 25/15 = 1.67. Rather than repeat my description of the importance of PEG valuation for growth companies, I refer you to my two previous articles:

  • Categorizing Tech Companies' Valuation Risk.
  • Nvidia: It's All About Growth.

The most important thing to remember is that a lower PEG is better, and 1.0 is the "normal" target.

Below is my recomputed PEG ratios for the top tech companies. I also included forward P/E as a reference and compared the companies' PEGs from last year to this year.

There was a significant improvement in PEGs overall, as reflected in median and average. This actually means that tech investments are less risky based on this measurement.

I classified them into four categories:

  1. Dark Green - These have a PEG of less than 1.0, so they have a P/E ratio reasonably balanced to their expected growth. These appear to be the most promising investment opportunities. I own all four of these stocks and will continue to hold them, possibly increasing my position.
  2. Light Green - These six companies have higher PEG ratios but remain below 2.0. I own all of these and will continue to own them, but Iâll keep an eye on them.
  3. Orange - With a PEG between 2.0 and 3.0, these companies are in a danger zone. I own IBM (IBM) and Cisco (CSCO) and will look at them more closely.
  4. Red â With a PEG greater than 3.0, I consider these stocks to have P/E ratios may not be justified by their growth expectations. I own Apple but may reduce my position depending on its new product announcements next week, even though it's one of my favorite stocks. I have a short position in Tesla (TSLA).

Nvidia's Improved PEG Ratio

The combination of significant revenue and earnings growth, lower stock price growth in the last nine months, and today's price decline has made Nvidia a stronger buy. Its forward P/E is now below 25X, down from 39.7X in my previous article.

More importantly, its PEG ratio is now well below 1.0 at 0.66, making. it one of the lowest in the comparison. In fact, it's now half of what it was nine months ago (1.36). Nvidia has already grown into its valuation.

Observations on the Other Companies

There are some other important observations as well.

  • Advanced Micro Devices (AMD) now has an impressive PEG of 0.66 as well.
  • All companies in the chart, except Alphabet (GOOGL) and Apple (AAPL), have improved their PEGs, and the average and median PEGs have improved substantially. This makes me more comfortable with tech industry investments.
  • Apple is a concern, and you need to watch its upcoming growth expectations.
  • Tesla is still way overvalued.

Conclusion

Overall, the tech companies are growing into their valuations, reducing valuation risk. Regarding Nvidia, it's an obvious Buy right now. There is, of course, risk in getting comfortable with its growth expectations, although at its current forward P/E and increased guidance it seems less risky to me.

data.title: MCN: Falls To A Discount, But Not Quite A Bargain Yet
data.description:
Written by Nick Ackerman, co-produced by Stanford Chemist

The last time we discussed XAI Madison Equity Premium Income Fund (MCN), it had been trading at a rather sticky premium. Today, the fund's share price has slid to a rather attractive discount relative to its net asset value per share. I believe that makes it a more interesting prospect today, though, looking back since our last write-up, that would have put some negative pressure on the fund's total returns. Further, if we look back further, the current discount still isn't looking like the bargain it may appear at first.

MCN Basics

  • 1-Year Z-score: -0.54
  • Discount/Premium: -6.26%
  • Distribution Yield: 11.73%
  • Expense Ratio: 1.10%
  • Leverage: N/A
  • Managed Assets: $138.339 million
  • Structure: Perpetual

MCN's investment objective is "a high level of current income with a secondary objective of long-term capital appreciation..." They look to achieve this with an "actively managed equity portfolio comprised of individual stocks and covered call options." Additionally, the fund will "pursue its investment objectives by investing in a portfolio consisting primarily of high-quality, large- and mid-capitalization stocks that are, in the view of the fund's investment sub-adviser, selling at a reasonable price in relation to their long-term earnings growth rates."

Performance - Discount Opens Up

Since our last write-up, the fund has seen relatively weaker total returns compared to the S&P 500 Index. This would have been partially due to the fund going from a premium to a discount. That would have resulted in the total share price returns being relatively weaker than the total NAV returns. At the same time, there were still some slightly positive total returns during this period.

Some could also easily argue that the S&P 500 Index is not a directly appropriate benchmark by which to measure MCN. That is quite true as the fund takes a much more balanced approach in terms of sector allocationâit is not so heavily technology-tilted as the major equity index.

Further, the fund employs an overwrite strategy. To factor this in, the fund provides a benchmark of the CBOE S&P 500 Buy/Write Index instead. Relative to that, MCN has delivered results that have been rather competitive over the longer term, but shorter-term results have fallen short.

Worth noting is that in 2024, the fund's name changed and the advisor changed; however, the same management team remained the sub-advisor, and the investment strategy of the fund remained the same.

In looking at the longer-term history of the fund's valuation, the current discount presents a more attractive entry price. However, it is also worth noting that the fund traded at a relatively outsized premium for a handful of yearsâthis would have naturally reduced the overall average level of the last decade. Before around 2021, an 8%-12% discount was not all that unusual.

Therefore, while in the short term it presents an enticing time to enter a position, I am not leaning overly bullish quite yet.

Distribution - Double-Digit Looking Tempting

In terms of the distribution, they actually switched to a monthly payout since we last touched on this fund. This is often seen as more attractive for income-focused investors, and they also kept the same equivalent amount being paid outâsimply going from $0.18 quarterly to $0.06 per month. Based on the current rate and price, the distribution yield comes in at a tempting 11.73%. On a NAV basis, this is a touch lower at 10.99%, thanks to the discount opening up.

At the same time, I had a similar warning during our last update that the fund's distribution is quite tempting, but this is fairly elevated for a call writing fund, at least relative to its CEF peers.

At the same time, they have paid out this same amount since going back to the Global Financial Crisis, so clearly, this is a level that they would like to maintain. After all, the longer they can keep it at this level, the more likely it is that the fund may return to a premium again one day.

The downside of this is that it becomes more difficult to continue to achieve the returns necessary. As an equity-focused fund, to cover the payout, it will require substantial capital gains to be generated. That can come via the underlying portfolio or the call-writing strategy. Should that not be achieved, then that means a slowly eroding NAV over time.

In the case of MCN, the NAV has been slowly heading downward since the end of 2021 to its latest fiscal year end, 2025. This is usually not a great sign, as it would indicate some difficulty in covering its payout from the income and appreciation necessary.

Therefore, that's why I believe the current distribution rate is not only elevated at a double-digit rate, which tends to be the rather common-sense red flag level, but also based on what the fund has been able to achieve.

In terms of tax purposes, the fund has classified the distribution primarily as ordinary income, but also as return of capital. For this fiscal year, it was a bit different because the fiscal year end was moved from lining up with the calendar year to ending Sept. 30, 2025.

MCN's Portfolio

When it comes to the options strategy, the fund is fairly heavily overwritten. The latest puts it at 86.5%, with the number of equity positions at 40 and option holdings at 44. The average contract length is also on the longer end relative to most peers that I look at in the call writing fund space, with MCN's average contract length at over 46 days. Eaton Vance, for example, often rolls contracts every two weeks. For the NEOS ETFs that have become quite popular, they write options monthly.

What key piece of information that is missing on the stats here would be how far out-of-the-money, or perhaps even, in-the-money, these contracts are. That could indicate potentially how much upside the underlying positions could participate in before they reach the covered call upside cap. Given the fund is heavily overwritten, this could be quite meaningful. On the other hand, the longer average contract lengths likely mean they can write a bit further OTM, while still collecting a decent chunk of premium.

In terms of sector weighting, information technology is the largest slice of the pie here, but it isn't overly overweight in the sector. Healthcare, financials, consumer staples, and energy all also come in quite closely in terms of their exposure as well.

With that, one of the more appropriate comparisons of MCN could be to a fund like the Invesco S&P 500 Equal Weight Income Advantaged ETF (RSPA). When looking back at the performance, we are quite limited due to RSPA's inception being in mid-2024. That said, so far, the results heavily favor RSPAâthat's even pretty meaningful in terms of the total NAV returns, MCN has slipped quite a bit, relatively speaking.

While this is past performance, it at least indicates a relatively poor result so far. That could always change moving forward, but I think it also highlights the fact that an even larger discount would be necessary for MCN before it starts to become worthwhile.

In looking at the top ten, the allocations are fairly hefty, with these representing just over 33.3% of the overall investments of the portfolio. At only 40 equity positions, this also isn't that unexpected.

In terms of unique exposure, I think the box is checked here. There are not many funds that have this assortment of top holdings being represented, aside from Amazon (AMZN) and Microsoft (MSFT) being regulars in most funds.

Conclusion

MCN provides investors a fairly unique portfolio with a portfolio that isn't overly emphasizing tech allocation. The fund managers then apply a covered call strategy on top. The fund is heavily overwritten, and that can run into the usual pitfall of covered call funds, limited potential upside due to being capped. The longer-term results of the fund put up competitive results against its benchmark, but the performance in more recent years has begun to falter. Along with that faltering, the fund's total share price returns have been even more negatively impacted, with the fund going from a premium to a discount. At this time, while it becomes a more interesting name to consider, I still wouldn't be looking to buy too aggressively here.

data.title: Novavax: The Bear Case Is Broken, But The Bull Case Needs More Proof
data.description:
Overview

Novavax (NVAX) continues to live up to its 1.8 stock beta after its shares rallied following the release of its Q4 earnings report.

When I wrote about Novavax last year, its stock was in turmoil after Health Secretary Robert F. Kennedy Jr. expressed concerns over the companyâs COVID vaccine, NUVAXOVID. Novavax was trying to achieve full approval for NUVAXOVID, but its BLA was delayed. This was a big deal because Novavax was set to receive a $175 million milestone payment from Sanofi (SNY) upon being granted full approval. I stuck with a âHoldâ rating on NVAX, noting its potential in a barbell portfolio.

A month later, the FDA approved NUVAXOVID, triggering the milestone payment.

Earlier this year, Novavax struck a licensing deal with Pfizer (PFE), allowing the pharma giant to utilize Novavaxâs Matrix-M technology âin products across up to two disease areas by paying $30 million upfront and up to $500 million in milestone-based payments.â

While the deal was relatively small and didnât move the stock much, it provided more credibility to Novavaxâs turnaround story.

Novavaxâs Q4 results are a âcherry on top,â featuring a net income (for a change).

The paragraphs that follow reassess Novavax to see if it's worth the recent hype.

Earnings

What pops out to me in Novavaxâs Q4 numbers is the surprising profitability and the revenue mix.

The EPS surprise of $0.11 was a combination of the Sanofi milestones ($50M in Q4) and a 40% YoY drop in opex.

And if you look at where the $147 million in revenue came from, Novavaxâs turnaround story becomes tangible. Licensing & Royalties generated $108 millionâ73% of total revenues. Direct Product Sales were just $39 million. In other words, Novavax is now essentially a royalty collection agency.

While managementâs FY26 revenue guide ($230M-$270M) implies a ~75% drop from the $1.1 billion reported for 2025, itâs a cleaner revenue stream. 2025 revenue was primarily composed of âpaper gainsâ from settling old contracts ($625M).

Now, managementâs revenue guidance did not include a potential $125 million milestone from Sanofiâs Phase 3 initiation of the COVID/influenza vaccine and a $75 million milestone from the tech transfer completion.

Just a few quarters ago, Novavax had âgoing concernâ warnings. But they ended FY25 with $857 million in cash and accounts receivableâenough to fund operations âinto 2028.â

This is a much different company. Novavaxâs past attempt to scale NUVAXOVID was met with commercial realities like a commoditized vaccination market, powerful competition, and decelerating demand. Today, large partners are paying big, high-margin bucks to utilize their technology.

Valuation

Part of Novavaxâs recent gains are associated with the market beginning to value its stock more like a "royalty-bearing enabler."

Two comparators that immediately come to my mind include Halozyme (HALO) and Royalty Pharma (RPRX).

Now, for what it is, I think Novavax is properly valued.

Unlike Halozyme and Royalty Pharmaâwho earn royalties on multiple approved productsâNovavax is enjoying the certainty of upfront and near-term milestone payments for now. A lot of the value in the partnerships theyâve struck is âbackloadedâ and dependent on uncertain clinical trial outcomes. Thenâof courseâNovavax is much more dependent on any one partner than are Halozyme and Royalty. Finally, Halozyme and Royalty have proven models that have consistently generated cash.

So Novavax should trade at a discount and, honestly, itâs probably a bit early for me to even compare the three. In any event, this is the type of model that Novavax is aiming for.

Pipeline

During the call, âC. diffâ was a popular topicâmentioned over a dozen times.

Unlike other indications within their pipeline (pictured above), C. difficile would be a much less crowded market than, say, RSV and shingles. So I think this is why Novavax focused so much on the preclinical prospect.

Previous C. difficile vaccine attempts have failed. There are a few reasons why. For one, older vaccines aimed to neutralize the toxins produced by the bacteriaâleaving folks colonized still. C. difficile is also contained within the GI tract, so vaccine protection requires mucosal immunity. And narrow antigen coverage may have been insufficient.

Novavax is aiming to target a variety of antigens and toxins, as well as curb bacterial colonization. Its Matrix-M technology may help enhance the immune response to hone in on mucosal immunity.

Elsewhere, Novavax is hoping to "shake more hands" for its internal COVID/influenza and influenza programs. Remember that Novavax prefers to secure a partner rather than funding a large, late-stage program all their lonesome.

Final Words

While Novavax has âturned a corner,â itâs still a ways from long-term assurance.

The companyâs goal of "profitability by 2028â is largely in the hands of Sanofi and the upcoming Phase 3 program for the COVID/influenza vaccine. If that one program slips/produces mediocre data, Novavax would take a hit.

Still, at the end of the day, Novavaxâs platform is its âsaving graceâ and serves as a pungent reminder to the importance of âmoatâ in this sector. If Novavax was merely dependent on NUVAXOVID as a stand-alone asset, this article wouldâve been written in a totally different tone.

That said, NVAX appears appropriately valued (maintain âHoldâ) and is a good candidate for a speculative position within the context of a barbell portfolio given its high-risk/high-reward nature. There is also still potential for regulatory risksâlike vaccine misinformation, BLA rejection, and license revocation.

data.title: Aspen Aerogels: A Long Road Ahead
data.description:
Shares of Aspen Aerogels (ASPN) have fallen to fresh lows after the outlook for the industrial and EV insulation manufacturer remains dismal, following a huge boom-bust cycle in the past.

With revenues having completely imploded now, the situation is dire, but there are some positive factors and expectations as well, although the situation remains highly speculative. A lack of execution and past disappointments make it difficult to build conviction, although the company still has time to (partially) recover from this.

Some Perspective

Aspen Aerogels started its corporate history as a provider of industrial insulation activities, this being a $100 million but lossmaking business when the company went public a little over a decade ago. Understanding what happened to the business is key, as multiple boom-bust cycles and strategic pivots explain why the company finds itself where it sits today.

After the company failed to generate sufficient revenues to achieve profitability, the company decided to reposition its business to provide solutions for EV batteries. This made it so that a share price of just a dollar ended up rising to a high of $60 in 2021, followed by a pullback to the low single digits in 2023. This was followed by a recovery to the $30 mark in 2024, with shares now back down again at just about $3.

These developments came as the company saw strong growth coming out of the pandemic. Revenues rose nearly 50% to $180 million in 2022 as growth slowed to 30% in 2023, yet growth accelerated to triple digits in 2024, which made the production capacity limits of $650 million come within sight.

To facilitate further and continued growth, the company was looking to build a huge new plant, at a nearly $2 billion bill, aided by the help of the DOE and external financiers. All this was driven by a strong 2024, with revenues reported up 90% to $453 million, accompanied by an operating profit of $53 million.

A Big Implosion

After the company guided for first quarter sales for 2025 to come in below the hundred million mark, the bigger news was that the company halted construction of its new and giant plant. Revenues quickly fell to a run rate of $300 million, with no realistic operating profits seen anymore.

All this stands in sharp contrast to the growth reported in the years before, attributed to oversupply of its solutions to EV manufacturers. Worse, with developments continuing in solid-state batteries, the company could be facing a long-term threat, as such batteries could result in much less demand for its products in the future.

Conditions remained brutal as third quarter sales of $73 million were still somewhat reasonable at a near $300 million run rate, yet the company guided for fourth-quarter sales to fall to just $45 million, to be accompanied by EBITDA losses of $10 million.

The company claimed that it could reduce EBITDA break-even levels to $200 million while maintaining a gross cash position of at least $100 million, as a new European contract might even bring in $150 million in revenues as soon as 2027.

More Disappointments

By the end of February, Aspen delivered disastrous results at the end of the year. Fourth quarter sales imploded to $41 million. Thermal barrier revenues, those being EV insulation revenues, fell to just $16 million, as lower demand no longer provided a valid excuse to call out capacity constraints for the energy industrial business. Revenues of that segment were cut more than in half to $25 million as well. All this weighed heavily on the P&L statement, with gross profits even reported at negative $23 million and GAAP operating losses reported at $70 million.

Worse, first quarter sales are seen down further to $35-$40 million, with adjusted EBITDA losses seen between minus $10 and $13 million; this actually marks a modest improvement from a negative $18 million number in the fourth quarter as the company works to lower costs. The company actually maintained a net cash position of just more than $50 million here, depending on the exact definition of net debt, as 82 million shares traded around the $3 mark, for a near quarter of a billion equity valuation here.

What Now?

What's clear is that expectations are very low, with Aspen's operating assets valued at just around $200 million. Moreover, while near-term losses will continue, some cash inflows are expected as well. In March, the company expects to obtain a $38 million cash payment from GM (GM) relating to a commercial settlement relating to EV capacity adjustments. Moreover, a non-binding LOI for the sale of the Georgia facility has been signed (at an unknown price) as the European customer announced in the fourth quarter was identified to be Volvo.

Even more extreme, reviews are seen for the commercial growth plans and the capital structure as the company continues to reduce the break-even point of the business. EBITDA breakeven levels for 2025 were seen at $270 million; this number is seen coming down to $200 million in 2026 and even a bit further into 2027.

Moreover, sequential revenue growth is seen in 2026, albeit that the bar is low, driven by recovery of GM volumes, greater subsea industrial orders, as well as recovery of the EV market at large.

In between sufficient liquidity, Aspen is not in real financial stress (yet) and certainly has a chance to improve its fortunes, but that requires great efforts, yet fortunately from a position of a net cash position. A combination of continued cost cuts and sequential revenue growth could be helping here, although much progress is needed.

All this remains highly speculative after investors in Aspen have been burned many times in recent times. While there appears to be a base underneath the business, and the company has some potential triggers, the reality is that the risk-reward might be reasonable, although this is a hugely speculative stance. We have higher conviction ideas at Value in Corporate Events, but will continue to monitor what happens next at the company.

data.title: Nvidia: Becoming The Berkshire Of Technology Is Bullish For Shareholders
data.description:
Nvidia Corporation (NVDA) just delivered an incredible fourth quarter where their revenue increased 73.21% YoY to $68.13 billion and exceeded the consensus estimates by $1.9 billion. The problem is that the market is unsure when NVDAâs revenue growth will peak and the increased amount of capital being deployed toward CapEx initiatives by the hyperscalers will disappear. This quarter should have alleviated the fears around the AI buildout, but we are seeing the market punish shares of NVDA as they have become a victim of their own success. Shares of NVDA sold off by more than -5% today and long-term investors are getting one of the cheapest valuations we have seen recently.

I believe that the downward pressure on shares of NVDA are a gift for long-term investors as we have all the data needed to understand that the AI infrastructure buildout still has a long way to go. Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Co (TSM) plans on spending between $52 - $56 billion on CapEx in 2026 which is an increase of 30% on the low side and we have seen the combination of Amazon (AMZN), Microsoft (MSFT), Meta Platforms (META), and Alphabet (GOOGL) expand their CapEx plans for the 2026 fiscal year by over 70% YoY to $610 billion.

When I look at the quarter from NVDA, when I look at the guidance, and when I look at the ecosystem that it is supporting, I believe that shares of NVDA are mispriced. The recent drop is likely to result in significant alpha for investors who are willing to ride out the current volatility. I am more bullish than ever about NVDA and this year could be significantly better than the one they just reported.

Following up on my previous article about Nvidia

Since my previous article about NVDA was published in November (can be read here) shares have appreciated by 3.22% while the S&P 500 (SP500) is up 4.94%. NVDA delivered a record breaking Q3 with 62.5% YoY revenue growth which took its valuation to less than 20 times forward earnings. The hyperscalers fueled NVDA's growth with massive CapEx investments as they evolved into the core infrastructure provider for the AI era. While Q3 was very strong their Q4 results were incredible and NVDA just broke several all-time records from revenue to profitability. I am more bullish than ever about NVDA as this is one of the cheapest valuations we have seen for the largest company in the market.

I am following up with a new article because I believe that NVDA is mispriced and the current valuation is creating a large opportunity for shareholders. The numbers from the Q4 print show that the best days are ahead for NVDA and I believe that shares will exceed $250 at some point this year.

The Q4 results and forward guidance show the AI Factory flywheel is still accelerating

NVDAâs Q4 results werenât just strong - it was a moment of reinforcement for the market as to why the market is treating NVDA as the core platform supplier to the global AI buildout rather than just a chip company. NVDA just generated $68.13 billion in revenue which was a 19.51% growth rate QoQ and 73.21% YOY. This quarter proved that NVDA is experiencing reaccelerating growth on a YoY basis. In Q3 2024 NVDA reached a 122.4% YoY growth rate which fell sequentially over the next year to 55.60%. In Q3 their revenue growth rate increased by 6.89% to 62.49% and in Q4 the revenue growth rate increased 10.72% to 73.21%.

NVDAâs data center division generated $62.3 billion in revenue in Q4 which was a YoY increase of 75%. In Q4 NVDA generated $51.09 billion in gross profit and $42.96 billion in net income which were both new records. NVDA maintained a 75% gross profit margin while increasing their profit margin by 7.08% to 63.06%. NVDAâs revenue growth and margin is expanding on a YoY basis and they just guided for $78 billion in revenue for their Q1 results which would imply that they are expecting a YoY growth rate of 77.02%. The AI buildout isnât stopping and the market is getting this wrong.

The bull case isnât dependent on one product cycle or one hyperscaler going against the grain as weâre experiencing a structural shift of how work gets done. AI workloads are becoming more inference heavy and more distributed which expands the opportunities for NVDA as their GPUs can be combined with networking, software and full stack systems.

NVDA outlined $11B of networking revenue in Q4 and discussed how it led to $31 billion of revenue this year. NVDA is seeing strong adoption in NVLink, Spectrum-X Ethernet, and InfiniBand as their customers are unifying distributed data centers into AI factories. On the earnings call, NVDA discussed that Blackwell Ultra can deliver up to 50x better performance and 35x lower cost for agentic AI compared to Hopper. They are positioning the Vera Rubin cycle as the next platform that will be a continuation of the AI factory buildout wave. The Rubin platform which is six new chips will target a 10x reduction in inference token cost compared to Blackwell and they are expecting that the hyperscalers will be the first to deploy these systems.

This is super bullish for NVDA because the roadmap of future chips are being absorbed as quickly as NVDA can ship them. The way that I am looking at this is that as AI becomes agentic its always on and compute is no longer a one-time training event as it becomes a recurring necessity. We are seeing that networking is scaling which is likely to enhance the flywheel.

The reality is that the combination of META, MSFT, AMZN, and GOOGL allocated $140.13 billion towards CapEx in 2023 then increased their spend by 55.04% ($77.14 billion) in 2024 to $217.27 billion. This year the CapEx spend from these companies increased to $357.51 billion as it grew YoY by 65.55% ($140.24 billion). For the 2026 fiscal year, these companies are projecting to allocate $610 billion toward CapEx which is an additional $252.49 billion and a YoY growth rate of 70.63%. These companies have the balance sheets and the cash flow to fund this build out for years to come, and MSFT reports their full year results in the summer while guiding for the next year.

I believe that they are still in a "prisoners dilemma" situation, especially with the advancements in NVDAâs chips. If the Rubin platform can generate a 10x reduction in inference token cost compared to Blackwell and Blackwell deliver up to 50x better performance and 35x lower cost for agentic AI compared to Hopper these companies have no choice but to upgrade unless they all say no. Any company that doesnât upgrade will be at a disadvantage because they will have to charge more for compute and they wonât deliver advancements as quickly as their peers. NVDA is at the center of the AI revolution and the buildout doesnât look like itâs stopping anytime soon.

Nvidiaâs valuation is dirt cheap at these levels

Shares of NVDA just got cheaper as the stock is off more than 5% since the earnings print and the street increased their expected forward earnings. NVDA is expected to generate $8.26 of EPS this year and $13.07 in 2028. This is an increased of 58.32% over the next 2 fiscal years which is the most in the Magnificent Seven. NVDA is trading at 22.36 times this years earnings and 14.13 times 2027 earnings. NVDA is now trading at the cheapest valuation in the Magnificent Seven and companies such as Walmart (WMT) and Costco (COST) are trading at valuations that are double NVDAâs with less than half of the EPS growth.

I think that the numbers are showing that NVDA is being mispriced on overblown fears about how much more buildout is left in the AI revolution. At these levels, I believe that NVDA is providing investors with a great opportunity to unlock future value.

NVIDIA is becoming the Berkshire Hathaway of technology

NVDA confirmed that its finalizing its deal with OpenAI (OPENAI), and I couldnât be more excited. NVDA previously indicated that it would invest up to $100 billion in OpenAI and deploy at least 10 gigawatts of AI data centers with Nvidia systems. There have been reports that the number is closer to $30 billion and this comes after NVDA invested $2 billion into CoreWeave (CRWV) at $87.20 per share. NVDA also expanded their collaboration to accelerate the buildout of over 5 gigawatts of AI factories by 2030 with CRWV.

There are some in the investment community that are calling these deals circular financing as they are becoming more concerned that here is a financial bubble around AI. I am taking the opposite side of this and I welcome NVDA making investments in OpenAI and CRWV. I believe that NVDA is starting to become the Berkshire Hathaway (BRK.A) of technology, and believe that they should make more investments throughout the AI ecosystem as this is likely to be the largest technological revolution the world has ever seen.

The real question is what does a company do when they are generating $14.32 billion in net income per month? In Q4, NVDA generated $42.96 billion in net income which is $14.32 billion per month and on an annualized basis they generated $120.07 billion in net income for the year which was $2.31 billion per week. Based on the Q4 results, NVDA is on a run rate of $171.84 billion in net income for this fiscal year, which is 3.3 billion per week of pure profit. Companies can buy back shares, pay down debt, pay dividends, reinvest in themselves, or make investments with their treasure trove of profits.

NVDA has $7.47 billion in long-term debt on the balance sheet with $62.56 billion in cash on hand. They are already buying back $48.03 billion worth of shares. As a shareholder I love the idea of NVDA making investments into companies such as OpenAI and CRWV and hope it doesnât stop there.

When NVDA makes an investment into these companies it is trading cash for equity. Currently CRWV is trading at $96.39 which is 10.54% higher than where NVDA purchased $2 billion worth of shares at. This means that NVDA has shares of CRWV that were worth roughly $2.21 billion on the balance sheet, which is a better ROI then plowing the capital into bonds. The current funding round for OpenAI will place its valuation at $850 billion.

If NVDA allocated $50 billion towards the deal, they would own 5.88% of OpenAI, and if they allocate $100 billion toward OpenAI they would own 11.76% of the company. An investment of $50 billion or $100 billion is not a small amount but the reality is that both numbers will likely be a fraction of NVDAâs profitability this year. NVDA has the cash to make these investments and if OpenAI becomes a multi trillion dollar company over the next 5-10 years shareholders of NVDA will benefit a great deal by having a significant amount of ownership of it on the balance sheet.

The other aspect that many individuals are overlooking is that this isnât funny accounting. NVDA is making cash investments in these companies for hard equity that sits on their books. What these companies choose to do with that capital is their business. The fact that they will be buying more GPUâs from NVDA is an added bonus that NVDA will recognize 100% of the profits because they already traded the cash for the equity. The sale of the GPUâs is a completely separate transaction.

I think that a lot of people believe that NVDA is funding the future sales of GPUs with its own money which isnât the case. NVDA traded their capital for the equity in these companies and the sale of GPUS will be just an added benefit. Over time I believe that these types of deals will generate a tremendous amount of value for NVDA and their shareholders and I wouldnât be surprised if we see more deals like this from NVDA in the future.

Risks to investing in Nvidia

While I am bullish on NVDA there are several risk factors to consider. NVDA just delivered 73.21% YoY growth and guided for $78 billion of revenue in Q1 which would be 77.02% YoY growth and the market punished them. Shares are selling off after what could be the best quarter in the history of the stock market as no company this size has ever grew their quarterly revenue by 73% YoY. Even though revenue is reaccelerating the market is clearly concerned about when the revenue growth will slowdown and when the CapEx buildout will turn from expansion to maintenance. NVDA is at the mercy of the hyperscalers deploying CapEx and if the market can convince them that they are spending too much on AI infrastructure the recent selloff after Q4 earnings may look mild compared to what could happen.

NVDA is a victim of its own success, and the fact that it couldnât break out after this quarter could be a signal that we have seen a top in its shares. Investors should do their own due diligence, as there isnât going to be a bell that signals the investments into the AI revolution are curtailing.

Conclusion

This was another drop the mic moment for NVDA as their Q4 revenue signaled the reacceleration of growth wasnât a fluke in Q3. I am shocked that shares sold off more than -5% after earnings as the analyst community is signaling that NVDA will deliver roughly $259.34 billion in revenue which is a 66.41% YoY growth rate. NVDA is now trading at the cheapest levels the market has seen is quite some time as investors are able to pay less than 24 times this year earnings and less than 20 times next years earnings.

After reading through the earnings call and looking at the data from the hyperscalers, I donât believe we are anywhere close to the AI buildout being over as each generation of NVDAâs chips provide advancements that they are unable to live without. The market is punishing many companies related to the data center buildout which is creating an opportunity for long-term investors. While the markets can be irrational at times I believe that shares of NVDA will rebound and have a good chance of reaching $250 in 2026.

Editor's Note: This article discusses one or more securities that do not trade on a major U.S. exchange. Please be aware of the risks associated with these stocks.
